title: No 10 says Cameron's wife and children do not benefit from offshore funds â as it happened | Politics | The Guardian
summary: no 10 says cameron 's wife and children do not benefit from offshore funds .
cameron denies owning shares , but ducks question about benefits from offshore trust .
cameron 's answer on the offshore trust - analysis .
what cameron said about the panama papers and his family - full transcript .
david cameron 's q & a on europe .
corbyn says cameron needs to come clean about his family finances and the offshore fund .

documents.title: afternoon summary
text: david cameron has tried to close down the controversy about his late father 's involvement with an offshore investment fund by issuing two statements insisting he is not a beneficiary .
during a q & a in birmingham he said that he did not own any shares , or have money in offshore trusts or funds .
despite being asked about his family , he only spoke about his own arrangements .
later number 10 responded to ongoing pressure by issuing a statement saying his wife and children do not benefit from offshore funds .
( see 4.57pm . )
but he has still not addressed the question of whether he benefited from his father 's investment in the past .
jeremy corbyn has said the government should consider imposing direct rule on british overseas territories and crown dependencies to stop them acting as tax havens .
labour has accused the government of watering down its plans to impose transparency on tax havens .
originally the government said they would have to publish public registers showing the beneficial ownership of companies registered in their territory ( ie , the names of the real owners ) .
but now the government is just focusing on getting tax havens to make this information available to other tax authorities , labour says .

seema malhotra , the shadow chief secretary to the treasury , said : the tories ' have watered down their commitment to taking action on tax havens in british overseas territories and crown dependencies .
they promised action back in 2014 , but two years on no progress has been made .
instead , they have quietly dropped their demands for public transparency in tax havens , leaving british taxpayers to carry the burden for those who are not paying their fair share .
labour also issued this chart illustrating their argument .

labour analysis of progress towards open register of beneficial interests party/labour party farmers will lose out by as much as ¬34,000 ( â£ 27,400 ) a year if the uk votes to leave the eu , unless new national taxpayer subsidies are put in place to bolster farm incomes , a new study has found .
sajid javid , the business secretary , has said he wants tata to agree a process for selling its uk steel business when they meet in mumbai on wednesday .

nicky morgan 's plans to force all schools in england to become academies is an attempt to turn education into a business and destroy the public service ethos of teachers , according to the head of one of britain 's teaching unions .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments
here is some twitter comment on the latest number 10 statement .
from the sun 's tom newton dunn tom newton dunn ( @ tnewtondunn ) sam cameron may have interesting tax arrangements .
no10 : `` mrs cameron owns a small number of shares connected to her father 's land '' .
from the telegraph 's christopher hope christopher hope ( @ christopherhope ) david cameron looks like he has been bounced into his extraordinary teatime tax disclosure by jeremy corbyn .
weak .
from the sun 's harry cole harry cole ( @ mrharrycole ) shares in land point to a company set up to run said acreage .
any losses such a company might suffer could be written off against tax bill .
it is worth pointing out that the new number 10 statement , like david cameron 's earlier comment , is framed in the present tense .
it does not address what might have happened in the past .
number 10 are briefing that it is put up or shut up time for david cameron 's critics , according to the bbc 's norman smith .
norman smith ( @ bbcnormans ) number ten say its `` put up or shut up '' time for those questioning the cameron family 's tax affairs

documents.title: no 10 says cameron 's wife and children do not benefit from offshore funds
text: number 10 has issued a statement giving more detail about the cameron family finances .
a no 10 spokesperson said : to be clear , the prime minister , his wife and their children do not benefit from any offshore funds .
the prime minister owns no shares .
as has been previously reported , mrs cameron owns a small number of shares connected to her father 's land , which she declares on her tax return .

sir vince cable , the lib dem former business secretary , has used twitter to express support for jeremy corbyn 's suggestion that the government should consider imposing direct rule on overseas territories and crown dependencies acting as tax havens .
vince cable ( @ vincecable ) cameron must n't be bullied on tax by rogue micro states .
demand open register of ownership .
use direct rule on british virgins and caymans .
update : cable first spoke in favour of imposing direct rule on tax havens on newsnight last night .
corbyn endorsed the proposal when asked about it this morning .
so really it is corbyn backing cable 's idea , not the other way round .
here is the number 10 account , or readout as they call it , of the meeting this morning between david cameron and carwyn jones , the welsh first minister to discuss steel .
the prime minister was clear that the shared overall goal is to find a buyer who can provide a long-term , sustainable future for tata strip products .

both the prime minister and the first minister agreed that the two governments are on exactly the same page and must continue to work closely together to secure steelmaking at port talbot and more widely .
the business secretary provided an update on the sales process and meetings with tata .

he outlined his meeting with senior executives from tata in london yesterday and how he would travel to mumbai today for meetings with tata chairman cyrus mistry where they will discuss the details of the sales process for tata 's uk steel operations .

the prime minister and chancellor highlighted the business secretary 's leadership in organising the steel council meeting , and leading other discussions within the eu , as a clear demonstration that the uk government was acting .
they discussed how the uk government has supported action on steel dumping at the eu level and would continue to push for more action to support the steel sector .
the prime minister and first minister finished by agreeing they should continue to meet regularly .
here is some more comment on what david cameron had to say about his late father 's offshore investment fund .

from the sunday times 's tim shipman tim shipman ( @ shippersunbound ) all these cameron statements leave open the possibility that his mum or the family is a beneficiary of an offshore trust from the daily mirror 's kevin maguire kevin maguire ( @ kevin maguire ) cameron 's very good at saying a little to hide a lot .
suspect he 's done it again on his family and the tax haven
itv 's robert peston has written a facebook post about david cameron 's comments about his late father 's offshore investment fund .
peston says number 10 implied he was being impertinent when he tried ( unsuccessfully , so far ) to get clarification as to whether cameron 's comments applied to his wife too .
during his q & a david cameron also insisted that being in the eu was not harming the british steel industry .
asked if eu regulations were damaging the industry , he said he did not accept that .
steel producers would be better off if britain remained in because more than half of british steel went to the eu , he said .
and if britain were outside it could be subject to the anti-dumping tariffs that the eu is imposing on china , he said .
he went on : it is a tough trading world out there .
we need those european markets open .
we need strength in numbers through europe to make sure we crack down on the dumping of chinese and other steel .
and britain is leading the way in making sure that happens .

documents.title: cameron 's answer on the offshore trust - analysis
text: let 's be blunt .
david cameron did n't answer the question .
as you can see from the full transcript ( see 3.25pm ) , sky 's faisal islam asked a question about david cameron and his late father 's offshore trust that was both precise and wide-ranging .
he did not just ask ( or even ask , if we 're going to be pedantic ) if cameron was benefiting from the trust now .
he asked if he had benefited from it in the past , or would in the future .
and he did not just ask about cameron personally ; he asked about cameron and his family .
cameron did his best to avoid sounding evasive ( note that sure as he starts to reply ) and his answer went on for some time .

but , on the subject of his finances , he gave a narrow ( and no doubt carefully rehearsed ) answer ; he does not own shares , does not have money in an offshore trust or fund , and the only income he receives comes from his salary , some interest and rent on his house .
he did not talk about other members of his family .
and he did not say whether he might have benefited from blairmore money in the past .
at a press conference reporters would have had the chance to press him repeatedly for answers on these points .

but cameron almost never holds proper press conferences in the uk ; his preferred modus operandi is to take two or three queries from reporters at events like this where the rest of the questions come more deferential members of the public .
today is a good example of why .
and yet - cameron will probably get away with this .

he plays the media well and , faced with a situation like this , has a pretty good sense of how to say just enough to satisfy people ( or at least those people willing to give him the benefit of the doubt ) but without admitting anything too incriminating .

as i write the guardian 's website is leading with the headline cameron ducks question about benefiting from offshore trust , but the daily mail 's version is more generous : david cameron denies he gets any income from his late father 's tax haven company .
and , of course , if cameron had tried to answer islam 's question in full , where would he have stopped ?
does family mean just his wife ?
or his children ?
or his siblings , and their children too ?
and how far back into the past should he have to go in terms of telling us whether he ever benefited from blairmore ?
as a conservative party official in his 20s cameron bought a flat in a smart area in notting hill and drove a bmw ( but a battered one , according to one of the cameron biographies ) .
presumably his father helped him out .

but none of us are responsible for our parents , cameron has never pretended to be anything other than privileged and he must be calculating that , on this , he has opened up about as much as is necessary .
david cameron at pwc in birmingham /reuters

documents.title: what cameron said about the panama papers and his family - full transcript
text: here is a transcript of what david cameron said to sky 's faisal islam about the panama papers revelation and whether or not he benefits , or has benefited , from the offshore trust run by his late father .
fi : the leader of the opposition has called for an investigation into your tax affairs for your own interests .
can you clarify for the record that you and your family have not derived any benefit in the past and will not in the future from the offshore blairmore holdings fund mentioned in the panama papers ?
dc : sure .

look , the investigation we need , first of all , is for hmrc , our tax authority , to use all the information that is coming out of panama to make sure that everything is done , to make sure that companies and individuals are paying their taxes properly .
in many ways what is coming out of panama is what we are introducing in our own country , which is a register of beneficial ownership , so everyone can see who owns what company .
the two things i 'm responsible are my own financial affairs and for the tax system of the united kingdom .
in terms of my own financial affairs , i own no shares .

i have a salary as prime minister and i have some savings , which i get some interest from and i have a house , which we used to live in , which we now let out while we are living in downing street and that 's all i have .
i have no shares , no offshore trusts , no offshore funds , nothing like that .
and , so that , i think , is a very clear description .
the second thing i 'm responsible is our tax system , and for international tax policy .

and i would say that no government , no prime minister , has done more to make sure we crack down on tax evasion , on aggressive tax avoidance , on aggressive tax planning , both her in the uk and internationally .

so we have recovered billions of pounds in our country by changing tax regulations and rules in budget after budget , billions of pounds , but we have also led the world in making sure we have - which we will have in june - an open register of beneficial ownership so everyone can see who owns what in britain .
we have n't just done that here in the uk .
we have also pioneered that abroad .

we have said , for instance , to the overseas territories and crown dependencies that they have to have the automatic exchange of tax infomation , they have to have a single standard for reporting company taxation and they too need to do registers of beneficial ownership .
and we have made huge progress on that with the overseas territories , with the crown dependencies and other countries as well .

i started this at the g8 summit in northern ireland some years ago and we have now got country after country sharing tax information , committing to beneficial ownership registers , which we 've never had before .
is there more to do ?
absolutely .
am i committed to doing it ?
absolutely .
and the anti-corruption summit that we are holding in london on may 12 will be yet another mark along the way of making sure that we deliver on this absolutely vital agenda .
we have low taxes here in britain , but low taxes that people must pay .
and that is our agenda , and we 're going to stick to it .
update : here is the audio .
here is a transcript of what david cameron said to sky 's faisal islam about the panama papers revelation is now here , at 3.25pm .
here is the start of the press association story about david cameron 's comments .
david cameron has said he has no shares , no offshore trusts , no offshore funds , after questions were raised about his family 's tax affairs following the panama papers data leak .
labour has demanded an independent investigation into the tax affairs of those implicated by the records , which includes details about the prime minister 's dead father , ian cameron .
during a visit to birmingham , mr cameron said the information should be used to ensure that companies and individuals are paying the tax they should but sidestepped calls for a probe .
he said : in terms of my own financial affairs , i own no shares .

i have a salary as prime minister and i have some savings , which i get some interest from and i have a house , which we used to live in , which we now let out while we are living in downing street and that 's all i have .
i own no shares , no offshore trusts , no offshore funds , nothing like that .
and , so that , i think , is a very clear description .
cameron has now finished .
he implied earlier that he was going to take another question from the press , but in the event he did n't .
so , by my count , he only took two questions from journalists - one from sky 's faisal islam , and another from a midlands reporter about steel .
that meant journalists were denied the chance to press him again on the question that islam raised ( see 2.49pm ) and to which he did not get an answer .
cameron is still taking questions .
this , from the daily mail 's jason groves , refers to an answer he gave a few minutes ago .
jason groves ( @ jasongroves1 ) cameron hints at u-turn on steel tariffs : 'we need strength in numbers thru the eu to crack down on the dumping of chinese steel . '
here is my colleague rowena mason 's assessment of david cameron answer to the panama papers question .
rowena mason ( @ rowenamason ) pm careful reply on tax affairs does not quite answer qu of whether his family has benefited from or cd benefit from blairmore in future

documents.title: cameron denies owning shares , but ducks question about benefits from offshore trust
text: q : [ from sky 's faisal islam ] jeremy corbyn has called for an investigation into the panama revelations .
can you clarify that you and your family have not received a benefit from blairmore holdings fund ?
cameron says hmrc need to investigate this , using the information coming out of panama , to make sure people are paying their tax .
what is coming out of panama is effectively what the government is introducing in the uk , he says - a system allowing people to know the beneficial owners of shares .
he says he is responsible for his own finances , and for the nation 's tax system .
he says he owns no shares .
he has a salary , and he has some savings , which he gets some interests from , and he has a house , which he lets out .
he has no shares or offshore funds .
he is also responsible for the tax system .
he says no prime minister has done more to crack down on tax evasion and tax avoidance .
the government has recovered billions of pounds this way , he says .
he says the government has also told crown dependencies and overseas territories that they will have to have registers of beneficial ownership too .
many countries are committed to this , he says .
he says there will be an anti-corruption summit in the uk to push this agenda further .
cameron says he does not own shares or offshore funds .
but he does not answer on behalf of other members of his family .
he sidesteps questions about whether he benefited from his late father 's offshore fund .
he claims no prime minister has done more to tackle tax avoidance .
david cameron holding his q & a with employees at pwc in birmingham furlong/pa
channel 4 news 's michael crick thinks today 's location is appropriate .
michael crick ( @ michaellcrick ) cameron prepares to address workers at pwc in birmingham , a firm which knows a thing or two about tax avoidance
q : the midlands engine has been mentioned in the last two budgets , without much detail .
if we stay in , how will we stay top of the agenda .
cameron says people in the west midlands sometimes think they will lose out because of the northern powerhouse .
that is not the case , he says .
cameron is going to take two more before he goes to the press .
( he is warming up before he faces the tricky question . )
asked about the motor industry , he says this has been transformed .
we make more cars in the north east of england than they do in the whole of italy .
cameron is now taking questions .
q : [ from a pwc employee who is the eu grants lead , focusing on the horizon programme ] what is the plan if we leave the eu ?
cameron says the horizon programme helps to fund universities .
this is really a question for the out camp to answer , he says .
he says british universities want britain to stay in .
cameron says it is only 70 years since europe was at war .
attending eu conferences can be frustrating .
but it is so much better than what came before , he says .
he finishes his speech by urging people to vote , whatever their views are .
cameron says there are 78 days to go until the eu referendum .
david cameron is starting with his standard stump speech on the case for staying in the eu .
he says he wants to focus on the economic case for remaining in .
britain would be better off in , he says .
he says services , like those provided by pwc , account for 80 % of the economy .
he says some of those backing brexit have said the uk should have a canada-style free trade deal with the eu .
but that does not cover services , he says .
he says a canadian airline can fly to a european city , but it can not offer services between european cities .
and british broadcasters can broadcast within the eu .
canadian broadcasters can not , he says .
david cameron speaking at the pwc office in birmingham

documents.title: david cameron 's q & a on europe
text: david cameron is doing a q & a on europe in birmingham .
he is at the pwc hq .
jack straw , the former labour foreign secretary , told the world at one , that jeremy corbyn was right to call for tougher action on tax havens .
but he said direct rule might not be the best approach .

the world at one ( @ bbcworldatone ) jack straw says `` international pressure '' and `` cajoling '' better than direct intervention in british overseas territories # panamapapers # wato straw went on : direct rule is easier said than done .

i certainly believe that given these revelations jeremy corbyn is quite correct to say the government has now got to come forward with a much tougher plan for the regulation of the british overseas territories .

had i known about the scale of tax avoidance , to put it at its mildest , that is going on in the british virgin islands when were were in government , then there was action that we both could and should have taken straight away .
but we did n't know .
he also rejected claims that labour neglected this issue when it was in government .

if you take gordon brown and alistair darling , these were people who were deeply and profoundly concerned about tax avoidance and tax evasion , both dour scots who disapproved of all of that , as did i and the government as a whole .
so we had no book for tax avoiders or tax evaders whatsoever .
my colleague rowena mason is at the event where david cameron is due to speak shortly .
she suspects he wo n't be keen to take questions from the press .
rowena mason ( @ rowenamason ) media at cameron speech must wear bright yellow tags .
like he does n't want to accidentally let us ask about his tax affairs or something
here are some more showing jeremy corbyn on the campaign trail in harlow today .
jeremy corbyn , gestures at a baby as he speaks with customers during a visit to a cafe in harlow , england .

mr corbyn visited the essex town to launch court/getty images jeremy corbyn chats with a supporter during a visit to a cafe in harlow court/getty images jeremy corbyn speaks to residents bridget mcalpine ( l ) and laura mcalpine as he campaigns door to door during a walkabout around harlow mckay/epa jeremy corbyn campaigns with labour supporters after he launched labour 's official local election campaign at mark hall & netteswell community assoc , moot house in harlow ansell/pa
the bbc 's norman smith ( unlike the sun 's tom newton dunn - see 12.19am ) thinks jeremy corbyn 's media team are sharpening up their act .
he explains why in his short video .
the bbc 's norman smith on whether team corbyn is getting its media act together

on the subject of local election benchmarks ( see 1.08am ) it is worth pointing out that jon trickett , the shadow communities secretary and who is in charge of labour 's election campaign , has used an article for labourlist to say that as long as the party does better than last year it will be making progress .
here 's an extract .
the english council seats we are contesting this year were last fought in 2012 .
the results then were labour 's best in the local elections since those that took place in 2001 on the same day as blair 's second landslide election .
in britain , politics has become much more fragmented since 2012 with the continued rise of ukip and nationalist parties in scotland and wales .
at the end of the day , we should be looking for labour to advance on the 2015 election results , where we finished almost seven per cent points behind the conservatives .
as politicshome reports , michael dugher has criticised trickett 's analysis , accusing him of getting his excuses in early .
dugher told politicshome : if anything , the tories should be there for the taking .
now is not the time to be throwing the towel in .
it 's all to play for in the english local elections and history shows that new leaders of the opposition and opposition parties in non-general election years need to do extremely well .
back to steel , and the meeting at number 10 this morning .

afterwards carwyn jones , the welsh first minister , struck an upbeat note , saying that the uk government and the welsh government shared a common goal of saving the welsh steel industry and that it was heartening that david cameron was taking no options off the table .
jones said : i think it 's fair to say the uk government and ourselves are in the same position .
we want to preserve these jobs in our communities .

we identified areas that need to be dealt with the issue of pension liability , that needs to be dealt with in order to make our plans attractive in terms of a sale ; energy prices in the uk ; and of course the issue of tariffs and the uk government indicated it was looking very carefully in these areas in order to improve the situation for steel .
david williamson has a full account here , at wales online .
carwyn jones speaking to journalists outside number 10 .
wermuth/reuters
earlier i quoted what dominic grieve , the conservative former attorney general , told the today programme about david cameron and his late father 's offshore investment fund .
( see 9.52am . )
as political scrapbook reports , grieve also used the interview to defend the right of places like the british virgin islands to operate as tax havens .

grieve told today : if we 're going to destroy the economy of the british virgin islands , which is because we prevent them from providing banking services at all , then we 're going to destroy the livelihood of its inhabitants i think the government has a responsibility towards encouraging overseas territories to find legitimate ways of economic development , and the financial sector is undoubtedly such a legitimate method .
mike smithson from political betting has written up an account of the political studies association this morning looking at likely outcomes in the may elections .
as reported earlier , the academics colin rallings and michael thrasher expect labour to lose 150 seats in the english local elections .
i 've been sent the briefing paper from the psa and it also includes these figures showing what rallings and thrasher expect the national equivalent vote to be in may .
the nev is figure showing what share of the vote would be if the whole country had voted , instead of just those places with a council election .
their nev estimate for 2016 is based on recent council byelections .

the comparisons are with 2012 because that was when this set of local councils last held elections rallings/thrasher nev forecast for 2016 local elections conservatives - 31 % ( down 2 from 33 % in 2012 ) labour - 30 % ( down 9 from 39 % in 2012 ) lib dems - 16 % ( up 1 from 15 % in 2012 ) ukip - 12 % ( up 7 from 5 % in 2012 ) michael dugher , the former shadow culture secretary and a strong critic of jeremy corbyn , says labour should be looking to gain at least 400 seats in the english local elections .
michael dugher mp ( @ michaeldugher ) jeremy is right .
labour should & must grow in may .
labour should gain at least 400 seats in the local elections .
the press association has more from jeremy corbyn 's post-speech huddle .

corbyn told reporters he wanted an investigation conducted by hm revenue and customs about the amount of money of all people that have invested in these shell companies or put money into tax havens and to calculate what tax they should have paid over the years .
asked whether the pm should resign if he is found to have benefited , corbyn said : let 's take one thing at a time .
we need openness , we need an examination , we need a decision after that .
pressed on whether he would publish his own tax return , corbyn said : there is no problem with my tax affairs , they are very , very limited indeed .
i have got an income as an mp , sadly i have got no family trusts of any sort .
this is what jeremy corbyn said after his speech when asked if he thought david cameron should disclose details of any family involvement with his late father 's offshore investment fund .
i think the prime minister in his own interests ought to tell us exactly what has been going on .
he also said there should be an independent investigation , unprejudiced , to decide whether or not taxes [ are owed ] .

but , as he made clear in his bbc interview earlier ( see 11.03am ) , he is calling for an investigation into the panama papers as a whole , not just into the offshore investment fund run by cameron 's father .
corbyn 's saying cameron 's tax affairs are not a private matter

documents.title: corbyn says cameron needs to come clean about his family finances and the offshore fund
text: it turns out jeremy corbyn did speak to reporters after all .
he did local interviews , and then did a huddle ( an informal , stand-up briefing ) with the national journalists who were there .
and he went further on david cameron .
corbyn says cameron needs to answer questions about his family finances and his late father 's offshore fund .
these are from my colleague jamie grierson who was there .
jamie grierson ( @ jamiegrierson ) cameron should tell public `` exactly what 's going on '' with his family 's financial affairs in light of # panamapapers revelations , corbyn says .
jamie grierson ( @ jamiegrierson ) asked if cameron should resign if it turns out he 's profited from offshore , corbyn says `` let 's take one thing at a time '' .

documents.title: corbyn 's speech - summary
text: tax havens are the story of the day and jeremy corbyn came out with a strong news line on this about half an hour before his speech at the labour local election campaign launch when he suggested that the government should impose direct rule on places like the british virgin islands to ensure they comply with uk tax rules .

his speech did not go much further , although it contained a colourful rhetorical line about tax havens being honeypots of international corruption , tax avoidance and tax evasion which will probably not go down well with the cayman islands legal community .
otherwise the speech contained a lively but routine critique of the tory record .
it did not contain any new policy , but local election campaign manifestos rarely do .
perhaps the most significant non-tax statement came right at the end , when corbyn seemed to set labour a benchmark for success in the local elections .
corbyn said he wanted the 5 may to be a turning point for labour where it starts to grow .

let may 5 be the turning point when labour grew , labour got support and labour showed there is a different , much better way of running this country for the good of all , not just the benefit of the very few wealthy people that have had it too easy for too long .

this is interesting because political leaders are normally loath to set themselves performance targets before elections of this kind - for the obvious reason that , if they miss them , they allow their enemies to say they have failed .
but corbyn seemed to be saying that he expected labour to gain more seats .

this is rash because at a political studies association briefing just this morning the academics colin rallings and michael thrasher said labour were on course to lose 150 seats in the english local elections .
( i 'll post more on this briefing soon . )

mike smithson ( @ msmithsonpb ) rallings and thrasher seat change projection for may locals con +50lab -150ld +40ukip +40 one final point : it was probably a mistake for corbyn not to take questions from the press afterwards .
admittedly , he had got his main point about tax havens across in the bbc interview earlier .

but refusing to take questions from reporters always causes immense annoyance to people who have decided to travel to an event instead of watching it on tv and , although pleasing fleet street is understandably about last on corbyn 's list of priorities , being willing to face reporters is sometimes just part of the job .
and today was about as a good a day for this as any ; rarely has the news cycle been so favourable to corbyn 's agenda .
the sun 's political editor tom newton dunn expressed his frustration about this like this .
tom newton dunn ( @ tnewtondunn ) hard to understand how corbyn/mcdonnell think they can be taken seriously as leaders when they refuse any questions at press conferences .
the event is over now .
after his speech , corbyn did not take questions .
i will post a short summary soon .

documents.title: corbyn says he hopes local elections will a turning point for the party
text: corbyn says a vote for labour is a vote for the message that it does not have to be like this .
let may 5 be the turning point where labour grew , he says .
corbyn says he hopes local elections will a turning point for the party .
corbyn says harlow council is building council housing .
but councils need to be allowed to do so on a much greater scale .
he says labour 's teresa pearce tabled an amendment to the housing bill saying homes available for rent should be fit for human habitation .
not much to ask , he says .
but the tories opposed that , he says .
corbyn turns to the elections .
electing a labour council is the best protection for your community against the onslaught from this conservative government .
even in the toughest of times it is labour councils that are making better choices : introducing a genuine living wage to tackle low pay .
dozens of labour councils across the country are boosting wages for thousands of people locally by insisting that all council contractors pay the real living wage to their staff .
corbyn says the tories are cutting money to the arts .
they are creating cultural deserts .
what is it with these tories , he asks .
he says the arts should be available for everyone .
there are 18,000 fewer police officers than there were a few years ago , corbyn says .
and there is a housing crisis , he says .
he says he was in bristol last week .
people there are shocked about how rents are going up , and the effect on the city centre , where areas are being socially cleansed because residents are being priced out .
and he attacks the conservatives for wanting to force schools to become academies , even though that wo n't benefit a single parent or a single teacher .
parents and teachers do not want this , he says .
labour will oppose it all the way .
corbyn says labour can still make a difference when it is in opposition .
it shamed the government into abandoning the personal independent payment cuts , he says .
and it forced the tories to scrap cuts to tax credits last year , he says .
he says the government 's cuts are a political choice , not an economic necessity .
corbyn says the government must ensure tata 's contracts continue .
and he makes an offer to cameron ; labour will help to ensure that there are no obstacles to a deal , he says .
this government 's ideological allergy to public ownership is stopping it taking the steps needed to save steel .
corbyn is now talking about the steel crisis .
some 150,000 people signed a petition calling for the recall of parliament over this issue .
but it was cameron 's decision , and he said no .
in wales the labour government there took a different decision , and the welsh assembly was recalled , he says .
corbyn is now talking about tax havens .
they have become honeypots of international corruption , tax avoidance and tax evasion , he says .
the government needs to go beyond warm words on tax dodging , he says .
there can not be one set of tax rules for the wealthy elite and another for the rest of us .
this unfairness and abuse must stop .
no more lip service .
the richest must pay their way .
jeremy corbyn is now speaking at the event .
he says he is the first labour leader for 80 years to have been a labour councillor .
he says harlow was built as a new town thanks to the vision of a labour government .
the post-war labour government did this in the aftermath of war , when the country was bankrupt .

he goes on : now this conservative government which tells us it can no longer afford nurses bursaries , can no longer afford student grants , that imposed the bedroom tax , this conservative government is prepared to spend over â£ 1 billion on the forced academisation of every school , shutting parents out of a say in the running out of their children 's schools , when even their own conservative councillors do n't want it , teachers do n't want it , and parents do n't want it .
this conservative government is making the wrong choices and has the wrong priorities .
i have taken this quote from the speech extracts released in advance .
there were some minor changes in what corbyn actually said .
the second speaker spoke about the nhs .
these speeches are addressing what labour says will be the four themes of its local election campaign .
according to a party briefing document , here are labour 's four key campaign messages .
labour 's campaign theme is standing up for you ' .
it epitomises labour 's promise of an economy that works for all with public services protected .
this is in stark contrast to a tory government which has shown it will not stand up for working people they are putting family prosperity and britain 's future at risk .
as part of this message labour will be prioritising four key areas which will be at the heart of its campaign .
they are : standing up for a fairer economy that works for all : creating an economy that delivers prosperity and security for all , not just those at the top .

we will get the deficit down fairly by investing to create a modern economy that delivers long term growth , and we will get the benefit bill down by creating decent jobs , tackling low pay and bringing down housing costs .
standing up for families struggling to get on the housing ladder : supporting working people by investing in new affordable homes to rent and buy .
our plans will bring down spiralling housing costs and control the housing benefit bill too .
standing up for safer communities : opposing deep tory cuts to frontline officers to keep bobbies on the beat .
we will prioritise neighbourhood policing and bear down on crime and its causes .
standing up for the nhs : investing in the nhs and joining up services from home to hospital with a properly integrated health and social care service .
and we will make sure that mental health is given the same priority as physical health .

documents.title: corbyn launches labour 's local elections campaign
text: jeremy corbyn is now launching labour 's local elections campaign at an event in harlow .
he started by saying he would be introducing some residents who will be talking about life in harlow .
the first man is speaking now , talking about the positive role that police community support officers play .
there used to be 35 pcsos in harlow , he says .
but now there are just five .
there is a live feed at the top of this blog .

documents.title: jeremy corbyn 's bbc interview - summary
text: here are the key points from jeremy corbyn 's interview with the bbc 's norman smith .
corbyn said the government should consider imposing direct rule on british overseas territories and crown dependencies operating as tax havens to ensure that they comply with uk tax rules .
[ the british virgin islands ] is a british colonial independent territory .
surely to goodness we can at least stop tax evasion and avoidance in british controlled territories .

this has to be addressed [ the government should ] say to the governments , those that administer the cayman islands , british virgin islands , and a number of other places , hang on , you are a government of a british dependent territory , a crown territory , you must obey uk tax law , you must not become a harbour for tax avoidance and tax evasion . '
[ imposing direct rule was ] done during the financial crisis in a number of cases where orders in council were used to impose direct rules .

i do n't particularly have a problem with that because if the local government in the area is simply going to condone this level of brass badge companies , tax avoidance and tax evasion , then that is something that has to be considered .
the point is that they are not independent territories .
they are self-governing , yes , but they are british crown dependent territories .
therefore , surely , there has to be an observance of uk tax law in those places .
if they have become a place for systematic evasion and short-changing the public in this country , then something has to be done about it .
either those governments comply or a next step has to be taken .
those dependent territories ' governments have got to understand the anger of people in this country when they read of this industrial scale tax avoidance and evasion .
he said this could be done very quickly .
direct rule can be done very quickly if that is what the government decides to do .
it can be done by an order in council .
it can be done almost immediately .
he said there should be an investigation into the panama papers revelations to see if tax could be recovered .
asked about the investment fund run by david cameron 's late father , corbyn said this should be part of the investigation .
he called for an examination of those that have placed money there [ in a tax haven ] , that appear to have done it to avoid tax and for the government to come after them to collect that tax back .
he also said the investigation must be independent , fast , thorough and fair so that we get to the bottom of this .
he said people engaged in offshore tax avoidance or tax evasion were taking money away from public services .
this is money that is taken from our health service , our local services .

the people that need it are losing out because of tax avoidance people who have made a great deal of money over decades by siphoning their wealth out of britain , putting it in a tax haven somewhere around the world , are actually shortchanging the people of this country .
he said he would be willing to publish his own tax return .
he only received income as an mp .
and he said ministers should be transparent about their earnings .
jeremy corbyn speaking to the bbc

here is is the key quote from jeremy corbyn saying the government should consider imposing direct rules on british overseas territories or crown dependencies acting as tax havens to make them comply with uk tax rules .

[ the government should ] say to the governments , those that administer the cayman islands , british virgin islands , and a number of other places , hang on , you are a government of a british dependent territory , a crown territory , you must obey uk tax law , you must not become a harbour for tax avoidance and tax evasion . '
[ imposing direct rule was ] done during the financial crisis in a number of cases where orders in council were used to impose direct rules .

i do n't particularly have a problem with that because if the local government in the area is simply going to condone this level of brass badge companies , tax avoidance and tax evasion , then that is something that has to be considered .
the point is that they are not independent territories .
they are self-governing , yes , but they are british crown dependent territories .
therefore , surely , there has to be an observance of uk tax law in those places .
if they have become a place for systematic evasion and short-changing the public in this country , then something has to be done about it .
either those governments comply or a next step has to be taken .
direct rule can be done very quickly if that is what the government decides to do .
it can be done by an order in council .
it can be done almost immediately .
those dependent territories ' governments have got to understand the anger of people in this country when they read of this industrial scale tax avoidance and evasion .
i 'm afraid comments are being pre-moderated today .
i hope this does not cause too much inconvenience .

documents.title: corbyn says government should consider imposing direct rule on uk overseas tax havens
text: jeremy corbyn , the labour leader , has just told bbc news that the panama papers reveal tax avoidance on an industrial scale .
this is money being taken from public services , he said .
he said the government should be able to ensure that british overseas territories and crown dependencies follow uk tax law .
asked if the government should consider imposing direct rules on places like the cayman islands or the british virgin islands , he said he would not have a problem with that .
this could be done very quickly by an order in council , he said .
he said those territories needed to understand the anger that people felt in this country .
asked about government claims that it is already addressing this problem , corbyn said that the government seemed to be talking a great deal about his , but doing less .
asked about cameron 's father 's investment , he said this should be part of an investigation into the panama papers revelations .
he also said he would have no problem publishing his own tax returns .
his income was what he received as an mp , he said .
corbyn says government should consider imposing direct rules on tax havens like the british virgin islands .
i will post quotes from the interview shortly .
on the today programme this morning dominic grieve , the conservative former attorney general , said public figures did need to be transparent in relation to their investments .
but he defended david cameron .

asked if cameron 's investments were really a private matter , as number 10 said yesterday ( see 9.15am ) , grieve replied : i understood he said he had no shares in offshore companies so that would appear to answer the question .
but he went on : i think with public figures ultimately we do have a need for transparency .

it 's worth bearing in mind we have a register of interests at parliament where we 're obliged to set out very clearly areas of our financial interest which go way beyond what ordinary members of the public have to do , and i 'm entirely comfortable with that .
here is a reuters from the cabinet room at number 10 , where david cameron has been meeting carwyn jones to discuss the future of the tata steel plants at port talbot and elsewhere .

david cameron ( l ) chairs a meeting about tata steel 's british assets , attended by business secretary sajid javid ( 3rd r ) , the first minister of wales carwyn jones ( 2nd r ) , and chancellor of the exchequer george osborne ( r ) wermuth/reuters

david cameron wants to focus on making the case for britain to remain in the eu today - he 's got an article on this subject in today 's telegraph , and we 're expecting him to talk in public about this later - but first he 's got a meeting on the tata steel crisis ( which wo n't help him win the referendum ) and at some point he 's going to have to address the story all over today 's front pages - about his late father 's involvement in an offshore investment fund .

neil henderson ( @ hendopolis ) guardian : the hidden deals that helped david cameron 's father avoid paying uk tax # tomorrowspaperstoday # bbcpapers neil henderson ( @ hendopolis ) mirror : so , do you still have family money stashed in a offshore tax haven , pm ?

# tomorrowspaperstoday # bbcpapers neil henderson ( @ hendopolis ) daily mail : cameron dragged into tax haven storm # tomorrowspaperstoday # bbcpapers neil henderson ( @ hendopolis ) the times : cameron 's father named in offshore tax scandal # tomorrowspaperstoday # bbcpapers at the number 10 lobby briefing yesterday the prime minister 's spokeswoman refused to say whether cameron still had family money in the fund ( which has the wonderful name blairmore - an apt summary of cameron 's politics , his rightwing critics would argue ) .
the spokeswoman said this was a private matter .
overnight number 10 has tried to be a little more forthcoming .
the prime minister does n't own any shares , sources say .
cameron himself is expected to say the same thing himself on camera later today .

but that is unlikely to stop people asking questions about whether he benefited personally in the past from investments in blairmore holdings inc , or whether any of his relatives have money invested offshore .
we will also be hearing from jeremy corbyn today .

at a labour event he will tell cameron to stop pussyfooting around on tax dodging but he has been scrupulous about not using family to attack his opponents ( he never asked cameron at pmqs about his mother 's opposition to tory cuts ) and he may be reluctant to personalise this issue too .
here is the agenda for the day .
9am : david cameron meets carywn jones , the welsh first minister , for talks on the steel industry crisis at number 10 .
10am : plaid cymru launch their manifesto for the welsh assembly elections in cardiff .
11am : jeremy corbyn launches labour 's campaign for the local elections at an event in harlow .
as rowena mason reports , he will say cameron must stop procrastinating when it comes to tackling tax avoidance and force the richest to pay their way .
afternoon : cameron is expected to take part in an eu referendum q & a .
as usual , i will also be covering other breaking political news as it happens , as well as bringing you the best reaction , comment and analysis from the web .
i will post a summary at lunchtime and another in the afternoon .
if you want to follow me or contact me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid .
i try to monitor the comments btl but normally i find it impossible to read them all .
if you have a direct question , do include andrew in it somewhere and i 'm more likely to find it .
i do try to answer direct questions , although sometimes i miss them or do n't have time .
alternatively you could post a question to me on twitter .

if you think there are any voices that i 'm leaving out , particularly political figures or organisations giving alternative views of the stories i 'm covering , do please flag them up below the line ( include andrew in the post ) .
i ca n't promise to include everything , but i do try to be open to as wide a range of perspectives as possible .

bulletin.text: Rolling coverage of all the day's political developments as they happen, including Jeremy Corbyn's launch of Labour's local election campaign and the row about David Cameron's record on tax avoidance.
Iceland prime minister resigns over Panama Papers revelations.
Revealed: the tycoons and world leaders who built secret UK property empires.
How to explain offshore banking (and when it is naughty) to a five year old.
